gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Metropolitan Government of Nashville and the Criminal Court Clerk of Davidson County, alleging that Rule 10(B) of the bail bond law violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree that required the court to enforce the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining the criminal court clerk from enforcing the rule against any third-party attempting to post a cash bail bond in Davidson County.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This case arose from the City of El Paso's allegedly unconstitutional debt collection policies and practices for Class C misdemeanor fines in connection with traffic tickets.[SENTMARKER]In doing so, the City actively misled plaintiffs to believe that they had just two options — monetary payment of their fines or jail.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.

gold_sents: In January 2016, two indigent women that served imprisonment terms at the Randall County Jail filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the City of Amarillo's municipal code created a modern-day debtors' prison and violated their Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the Court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss and ordered the plaintiffs to pay $3,660.00 in litigation costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The City of Amarillo is located in Potter and Randall Counties in the panhandle of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The City contracts with the Randall County Jail to house those who are ordered by municipal court judges to serve jail time for failing to pay a fine.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas in August 2016.[SENTMARKER]The Court held that it was a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment to jail indigent persons solely for not paying a fine, and that the city had violated the Constitution by failing to comply with the court's orders.

gold_sents: Foster children in Georgia's Fulton and DeKalb Counties brought suit against the state and counties Division of Family and Children Services.[SENTMARKER]The class of children alleged that they did not receive necessary treatment and services while spending months in emergency shelters, experienced abuse and neglect as a result of an insufficient number of caseworkers, and received inadequate health care and emotional services while in foster care.[SENTMARKER]In 2005 and 2006, the plaintiffs reached settlement agreements with the state, Fulton County, and DeKalb County.[SENTMARKER]As of November 2018, the State is still under the supervision of the independent monitor in order to meet the court-ordered benchmarks, having not yet completed sufficient improvements.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This class action was brought on behalf of foster children in Fulton and DeKalb Counties, Georgia, in October 2005 by the Children's Rights Project (CRP) and the Georgia Department of Human Services (DHS).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the foster children were frequently left in dangerous emergency shelters for months and sometimes years at a time.[SENTMARKER]The children were suffering emotional, psychiatric, and psychological problems as a result of their history of sexual abuse and neglect.[SENTMARKER]In October 2005, the parties entered a consent decree, which required the state to provide foster children with health screening, treatment for asthma, and aftercare/ongoing services.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, who are children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), brought suit against the state alleging abuse, neglect, and lack of services.[SENTMARKER]After the New York Times published several articles about the deaths of children in the care of DYFS due to lack of care, in 2003 the state entered into a settlement agreement providing for a systematic overhaul of the state child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The latest modification of the agreement was made in 2015 and remains in force.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services, Department of Human Services, and State of New Jersey (collectively, the "defendants"), on behalf of all children who are or will be in the custody of the Division (the "plaintiffs") filed this civil rights action against the defendants in the United States District Court for the District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate child welfare services, failed to adequately monitor the child welfare system, and failed to protect children from abuse and neglect.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to a settlement in which they agreed to provide services to children in need of services.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, children in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration ("CWA"), and children who, while not in the custody of CWA, are or will be at risk of abuse or neglect and whose status is known or should be known to CWA, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against both the city and state for systematic deficiencies that jeopardized their well-being.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed on December 13, 1995, and the parties reached to two separate settlement agreements, one with the city and one with the state, on December 2, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs returned to court in January 2001, seeking an order directing the state to comply with specific terms of the state settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the state had acted with insufficient diligence in implementing the information management system, and therefore extended the terms of the agreement in this area and directed that the plaintiffs receive semi-annual reports.[SENTMARKER]The defendants provided a January 2017 report to show that they were continuing to develop, implement, and update their information systems for child welfare needs.[SENTMARKER]A year later, the court ended its supervision of the portions of the settlement that it had retained jurisdiction to enforce.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights action on behalf of all children who are or will be in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as the appointment of a receiver.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in a related state court action.[SENTMARKER]The Court retained jurisdiction over the case, and the parties filed a motion in January 2001 seeking to enforce the terms of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: This was a class action challenge to New York's unnecessary institutionalization of children in foster care in psychiatric facilities.[SENTMARKER]The initial settlement agreement, entered on February 28, 2011, provided for increased community-based placement opportunities for children in foster care with mental illness as well as individualized planning, staff training, and monitoring.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the initial settlement agreement, on July 7, 2011, the plaintiffs agreed to release defendants from all liability in exchange for payment from defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2016, the parties agreed to extend the Court's jurisdiction until June 30, 2016, at which time its jurisdiction presumably expired.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 10, 2010, a group of children in foster care filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York Department of Mental Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Children's Mental Health Act (C.M.H.A.)[SENTMARKER]by placing the children in extended confinement in psychiatric hospitals.[SENTMARKER]The court certified the class as a class in 2010, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (i) The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $25,000; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the plaintiffs agreed not to sue the defendants in the future; and (iii) the case planning agency agreed to provide training to staff.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2013, an eleven-year-old child in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas, Abbeville County, South Carolina, against SCDSS and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS), alleging that, as a result of Defendants' failures, Plaintiff was sexually assaulted on multiple occasions, causing him severe and permanent mental injury.[SENTMARKER]Following removal to Federal Court, in early 2014, Plaintiff settled with both SCDSS and BHOTS for an undisclosed sum of money.[SENTMARKER]BHOTS also permanently closed as a result of the lawsuit.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2013, a resident of Abbeville County, South Carolina filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS) alleging that the defendants failed to adequately supervise a minor child in the custody of the SCDSS.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant failed to supervise the child and the child that assaulted him.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on March 10, 2014 by the court.

gold_sents: On January 12, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging numerous deficiencies in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2015, the parties reached an interim settlement agreement, providing for an end to certain SCDSS practices, as well as for studies of additional SCDSS practices.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring revealed incremental improvements in conditions, and the settlement remains in effect.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2015, the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina entered an order requiring the South Carolina Department of Social Services to address long-standing problems experienced by children in foster care custody and in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The order was entered in response to a lawsuit brought by the Children's Rights Project (CRP) on behalf of a child who was placed in a foster home in Aiken County, South Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state failed to adequately monitor the child's placement, failed to provide adequate services to the child, and failed to ensure that the child was receiving adequate care.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the state to implement a plan to address the children's issues.[SENTMARKER]The state agreed to implement the plan on September 28, 2015 and the case was closed.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a wheelchair-bound customer sued Chipotle in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, alleging that the food preparation counters at Chipotle restaurants were too high and violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered judgment against Chipotle for violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that the high walls violated the ADA because they did not provide customers in wheelchairs with full and equal access.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the district court ordered Chipotle to pay the plaintiff $136,537.83 in attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed this ongoing lawsuit on behalf of several LSAT test takers against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC).[SENTMARKER]The State claims that LSAC routinely denies reasonable accommodations to test takers with disabilities in violation of the California Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties have agreed to a consent decree that the court approved.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2009, the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) filed this complaint against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC) in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that LSAC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Unruh Civil Rights Act (UNR) by failing to offer the LSAT test in a manner accessible to individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which LSAC agreed to provide reasonable accommodation to individuals who were unable to take the test.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required LSAC to comply with other ADA and UNR requirements.

gold_sents: Disabled plaintiffs sued a public transit agency for violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging their bus system presented numerous barriers to access, subjecting the plaintiffs to delay, embarrassment, and ridicule by passengers and drivers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, in which the defendant agreed to remedy the problems with its bus system and pay $250,000 in damages, fees, and costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] Plaintiffs Jonathan Steele and Timothy Richardson, by and through their attorneys Fox Robertson, P.C., filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on January 12, 2001 against SST, a public entity that operates a fixed route bus system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that SST violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (R&A) by failing to provide disabled persons with reasonable access to public transportation.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive relief, compensation, and attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to extend the deadline for filing the suit.

gold_sents: Disabled patrons of a concert venue filed a class action against the owners and operators of the venue for failure to remove barriers to access.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Defendants agreeing not to obstruct wheelchair areas and to pay damages and attorneys' fees and costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The ADA and C.R.S.[SENTMARKER]24-34-601 prohibit the use of architectural barriers in designated wheelchair seating areas.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed not to place equipment or other obstructions in the designated seating areas and to pay the named plaintiffs in the form of a judgment.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 26, 2010, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak) to enforce Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and its implementing regulation, 49 C.F.R. Pt.[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires Amtrak to make its existing stations in its intercity rail transportation system readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities, no later than July 26, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Amtrak failed to comply with the ADA by failing to make the stations accessible.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the ADA required Amtrak to develop a final design and plans for ADA compliance.[SENTMARKER]On July 27, 2013, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement established a compensation fund for individuals harmed by Amtrak's lack of accessible transportation services.

gold_sents: On July 22, 2013, attorneys from United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the State of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that nearly two hundred children with disabilities were unnecessarily segregated from their communities and the general population by the State, which had placed them in nursing homes.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought an injunction requiring the State to comply with Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12131-12134, which, as interpreted by the Supreme Court in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 22, 2013, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed suit in the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Health, alleging that the state violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by unnecessarily segregated children and young adults with disabilities in nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Florida's policies and practices regarding the services it provides these individuals violate Title II.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in July 2013 with a consent decree that required the state to implement a plan to ensure that children with medical needs in the community are not unnecessarily separated.

gold_sents: In 2005, two organizations that advocates for people with disabilities filed this lawsuit n the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the City of Detroit, claiming that the city had failed to meet federal and Michigan accessibility standards in altering intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the parties negotiated a plant to correct the affected intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]As of 2018, a special master continues to monitor implementation of the agreement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 9, 2005, the Center for Community Access (CCA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Detroit.[SENTMARKER]CCA advocates for the individual and collective rights of people with disabilities in order to gain freedom of movement and access to the greater community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed for a preliminary injunction to correct access defects in the Bagley Avenue project.[SENTMARKER]On October 16, 2006, the court granted the plaintiffs' request for an injunction.

gold_sents: This was a case brought to make a 300 unit apartment complex in Canton Township, MI accessible to persons with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2006 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two individuals and the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The suit eventually resulted in about three quarters of a million dollars in retrofits, damages to the plaintiffs and attorney fees and costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan entered a final judgment in favor of the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan, Inc. against Beztak Properties Inc. and the Canton Township of Canton, Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment held that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by denying housing to persons with disabilities.

gold_sents: A class action lawsuit was filed on July 10, 2012, against the Mississippi Department of Education, under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA), alleging that the defendant had failed to execute its responsibilities under IDEA, by not ensuring that the Jackson Public School District provide disabled students with a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment, even after conducting an investigation into the School District and identifying its systemic failure to meet its IDEA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on September 29, 2014 stipulating the implementation of a Program Sustainability Plan for the 2014-2015 school year.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2015 District Court Judge Daniel P. Jordan III granted a motion to dismiss with prejudice.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 8, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi on behalf of children with disabilities in the Jackson Public School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the district had failed to provide them with the free appropriate public education they were entitled to receive under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA) and the Mississippi Department of Education (MDE) failed to meet its obligations under the law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on September 11, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which each party agreed to pay the other's costs.

gold_sents: On August 3, 2006, plaintiffs, a group of disabled persons receiving public benefits filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the South District of New York against the New York Human Resources Administration alleging that it discriminated against disabled persons by involuntarily segregating them by transferring their public benefits cases from local benefit centers to three hub centers that only serviced people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved a proposed settlement agreement in June of 2015.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2006, a group of disabled New York residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Human Resources Administration.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by transferring their cases to a limited number of hub centers, which were primarily for people in the shelter system.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on November 7, 2014 and the case was closed.

gold_sents: Students sued the New York City Department of Education, the City of New York, and the chancellor of the New York City Department of Education to seek injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and New York state law.[SENTMARKER]The student plaintiffs are either student in Staten Island District 75 schools or vulnerable to being sent to those schools, which are separated from New York City community schools.[SENTMARKER]District 75 students receive their education in a restrictive setting where they are largely isolated from interactions with students who do not have disabilities.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief in the form of a permanent injunction against future violations and an order for a remedial plan to reimagine policies, practices, and norms that will permit each student to learn in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2014, the New York City Department of Education and the City of New York were sued in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New Jersey by a class of Staten Island students with disabilities who were being educated in segregated and unequal public schools and classrooms in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) in the Staten Island District 75 schools.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOE did not employ a comprehensive or effective plan to enable students who are qualified for and who want to be educated in community schools to participate in integrated programs in the community schools and were separated from students who were not qualified for the integrated programs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a remedial plan that includes new practices, policies, and procedures to ensure that all students in the Plaintiff Class have the opportunity to be education in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs; .

gold_sents: Four blind or visually impaired library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking relief under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Library's new program to lend e-reading devices was discriminatory, because the Nook Simple Touch devices the library had procured were inaccessible to visually impaired users, and because accessible alternative devices were available.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The library agreed to transition to the exclusive use of accessible devices within four years, and to add ten accessible e-readers within 60 days of the settlement date.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2013, the Philadelphia Free Library of Philadelphia sued the City of Philadelphia in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for violating Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Library purchased 65 inaccessible NOOK devices when accessible alternatives were available.[SENTMARKER]The Library purchased the devices when the devices were not accessible to the blind or disabled patrons.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the Library's conduct was in violation of Section 504.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in March 2014 and the Library was ordered to pay a total of $160,000.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 15, 2014, plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against Millcreek Township, Pennsylvania, alleging violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA") and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Section 504").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and payment by Defendants of plaintiffs' reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the Court entered a partial settlement agreement between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into this settlement agreement, which is enforceable by the Court.

gold_sents: In 1996, parents of a student with autism filed this lawsuit on his behalf against the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District under the IDEA, the ADA, Section 504, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The parents claimed that their son was unfairly discriminated against due to his disability and was deprived of an appropriate education.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the Eastern District of Arkansas Court held that neither defendant had violated the federal statutes and found for state and the school district.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, Thomas and Dianna Bradley filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas against the Arkansas Department of Education, the Williford School District, and several school district officials.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to provide an adequate due process hearing to review their son's Individual Education Program (IEP).[SENTMARKER]In 1985, the court held that  504 lacked the required expression of intent, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Plaintiff filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Los Angeles Unified School District, alleging that he was discriminated against because he was a member of the Gay andStraight Alliance Network (GSA Network) in the school district.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the district violated the federal and state anti-discrimination laws by denying him the opportunity to enroll in an exclusive student leadership class.[SENTMARKER]The district denied the suit, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 2020, a group of Title IX complainants filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the United States Department of Education (ED) alleging that the agency's Title IX regulations regarding sexual harassment and assault violate Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 and the federal civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the ED's regulations significantly limit the ability of educational institutions to respond to reports of sexual harassment, assault, and discrimination in the form of a Title IX investigation.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the agency released a new rule in May 2020 that excluded sexual harassment committed abroad from Title IX protections, requiring that it be perpetrated "against a person in the [United States]."[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the new rule violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by the Office of Dispute Resolution and Complaint Management.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.

gold_sents: In 2012, a parent, individually and on behalf of their student-child with an educational disability in the Buffalo City School District, filed this class action complaint in the the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Buffalo City School District Board of Education and its superintendent denied free appropriate public education to children with educational disabilities, failed to promptly provide children with disabilities related services, and failed to provide parents with meaningful participation in their children's educational decision-making process.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required more timely speech and language therapy for members of the class and awarded attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in March 2015.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2011, three foreign residents of Indiana filed a class action lawsuit against the cities of Indianapolis and Franklin and the counties of Marion and Johnson, seeking to enjoin enforcement of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act 590, which would allow local law enforcement officers to make warrantless arrests of people who were subject to a removal order issued by an immigration court or a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or who had been indicted or convicted of an aggravated felony, and would make the use of consular identification cards for identification within the state a civil infraction punishable by fine.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2013, the District Court (Judge Barker) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, granting their motion for summary judgment, and permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 of SEA 590.[SENTMARKER]Because plaintiffs' suit was dependent upon enforcement of these sections, the matter was dismissed without prejudice.

Section 18 prohibits the use of consular identification cards for purposes of the I-9 Employment Eligibility Form. Section 20 allows the arrest and detention of people who have a notice of action issued by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) or a warrant issued by a federal immigration court.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Section 18 creates civil sanctions for people who use consular ID cards for identification purposes.[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, the court entered a preliminary injunction in favor of the plaintiffs enjoining the defendants from enforcing these provisions until further order.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2011, the plaintiffs filed their motion for summary judgment, and on April 20, 2012, the court granted summary judgment.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2012, the U.S. District Court for the District of Oklahoma entered a preliminary injunction enjoining the Defendants from enforcing the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2002 ("OCPA"), which requires the State to use the employment authorization system known as E-Verify in order to contract with the State.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2011, the Supreme Court of the United States issued a ruling in Chamber of Commerce v. Whiting, holding that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]On December 20, 2012, the District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Santa Fe County and its elected officials, employees, agents, and contractors responsible for the operation of the Santa Fe Adult Detention Center (SFCADC) pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act of 1997 (CRIPA).[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the SFCADC violated the CRIPA by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care, suicide prevention, protection of inmates from harm, fire safety, and sanitation, as well as the constitutional rights of inmates.[SENTMARKER]The County denied the allegations and entered into a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) with the DOJ in November 2004 to resolve the DOJ's investigation and ensure constitutional conditions of confinement at SFC ADC.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the County's motion for partial summary judgment and entered a final judgment in favor of the County.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.

gold_sents: In June 2014, a same-sex couple who had been lawfully married outside the State of Alabama filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that Alabama's refusal to recognize the marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into outside of the State violated the Due Process Clause and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent to the Obergefell decision in June 2015 by the Supreme Court, Judge R. David Proctor dismissed this case without prejudice in October 2015, and costs were to be taxed against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs’ appealed to the Eleventh Circuit in January 2016, but in February 2017, the Eleventh Circuit upheld the district court’s ruling that there was no judicially sanctioned change in the relationship of the parties that would justify an award of attorney’s fees.[SENTMARKER]Parties submitted informal notice that counsel no longer sought to pursue costs in this case in May 2017, and there has been no further action in this case.

gold_sents: In March and November of 2003, two separate cases (Clayworth v. Bonta and Cal. Med.[SENTMARKER]Assoc. v. Bonta) were filed by Medicaid service providers and recipients seeking to enjoin California from reducing its disbursement rate to Medicaid providers by 5%.[SENTMARKER]The cases were both filed in U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, and the Court found that the issues in the cases were substantially similar and therefore chose to relate them, assigning them to the same Judge.[SENTMARKER]The Judge at the District Court granted a preliminary injunction preventing California from implementing the rate reduction, finding that to do so would violate the federally guaranteed right to equal access to quality medical services for Medicaid beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant appealed, and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the lower court's decision, finding that their was no cause of action that would allow Medicaid providers or recipients to challenge a State's compliance with the equal access provisions of Medicaid.[SENTMARKER]The cases were later dismissed.

gold_sents: This lawsuit arose out of the funding provisions for elementary and secondary schools in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) of 2020.[SENTMARKER]Filed by eight states (California, Michigan, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin), Washington D.C., and four school districts (Chicago, Cleveland, New York City, and San Francisco), the lawsuit challenged a July 1, 2020 interim final rule from the Department of Education about how the funds may be distributed between private and public schools.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the interim final rule.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, the court approved a permanent injunction that prevented the defendants from implementing the April 30 guidance and July 1 rule and from taking any action inconsistent with the proportional share formula in Section 1117 or other restrictions or penalties on the use of CARES Act funds.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction over the case for enforcement purposes.

gold_sents: In 2010, the U.S. Congress passed the Affordable Care Act (ACA) (“Obamacare”) that expanded Medicare coverage to include additional groups of beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]Arkansas approved a work requirement in Medicaid as a requirement for health coverage in its amendments on March 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On August 14, 2018, three individuals filed a suit against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), as well as administrators involved in implementing the Arkansas Works Amendments (AMA) in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the SSA and the Constitution in approving the AWA in March 2018.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs were beneficiaries of Medicaid who lost or risked losing medical coverage due to changes in the AWA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief against the AWA and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 27, 2019, the court held that the AWA work requirement does not advance the purpose of the SSA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment and vacated the approval for Arkansas’s program.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2019, the defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On February 14, 2020, the Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's judgment vacating the Secretary's approval of the Arkansas Works Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court emphasized that providing healthcare coverage is the primary purpose of Medicaid.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' alternative objectives of better health outcomes, financial independence, and transition to commercial coverage, on the other hand, were not consistent with Medicaid.[SENTMARKER]The court found the Secretary's approval of the Arkansas program to be arbitrary and capricious due to the failure to consider whether the program would result in loss of coverage, an important aspect of the approval analysis.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This is an action for declaratory and injunctive relief for violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, the Social Security Act, and the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On March 5, 2018, the District Court for the District of Columbia held that the U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services' approval of the Arkansas Works Amendment was arbitrary and capricious because he failed to analyze whether the demonstrations would promote the primary objective of Medicaid.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered final judgment on April 4, 2019, and the Secretary filed a notice of appeal on April 10, 2019.[SENTMARKER]In short, we agree that the alternative objectives of better health outcomes and beneficiary independence are not consistent with Medicaid.

gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 21, 2012, an inmate at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (D.C.J.)[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) seeking injunctive and declaratory relief under RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that TDCJ policies burdened the exercise of his religious beliefs by preventing him from (1) smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, (2) wearing a religiously significant "medicine bag" other than within his cell and to and from religious ceremonies, and (3) growing long hair or alternatively, a kouplock, which is "a one inch square section of hair at the base of the skull."[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the inmate's claims in his official capacity, but retained his free exercise claims against a TDCJ program analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the district court issued its Opinion and Order on Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment ("Opinion and Order"), and Final Judgment was entered in Defendants' favor.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Fifth Circuit remanded the case to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit vacated and remanded on Plaintiffs' claim that the grooming policy violated their right to wear a "kouplock" consistent with their Native American faith, but instructed the Court to make a specific finding as to the admissibility of the testimony of the defendant's program analyst.[SENTMARKER]The court granted Plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in favor of Defendants on the grooming claim, but denied Plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.

gold_sents: On Oct. 14, 1997, two applicants who had been denied admission to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the university.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, claimed that the university's admissions policy treated race as a predominant factor in granting admission, and that they, as white applicants, had been discriminated against in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case went to the Supreme Court, which held that the school's admission policy that automatically awarded 20 points out of a possible 150 to underrepresented minorities was not narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling interest of diversity in education and so violated the Equal Protection Clause.

gold_sents: Two third-party nominees for the Georgia State House of Representatives filed this case alleging that, in light of public health risks associated with COVID-19, requiring them to collect over 20,000 signatures to get on the ballot violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, the court ordered the defendants to reduce the relevant signature requirements by 30% for the 2020 general election.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of Georgia residents filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, alleging that Georgia's ballot access restrictions unconstitutionally burden their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' complaint alleged that the state's signature-gathering requirements increased their burden.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the Secretary of State to reduce the relevant signature requirements by 30% for the 2020 general election.

gold_sents: This is a class-action suit brought by a nonprofit organization and an individual against the state of Georgia to challenge the state’s requirement to purchase postage stamps for mail-in ballots.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring election officials to provide prepaid returnable envelopes for absentee ballots and absentee ballot applications.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, the preliminary injunction was denied for the June primaries and on August 11, the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction was denied as to Count I of the amended complaint, and which was accordingly dismissed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2014, a group of Georgia residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the State of Georgia, the Secretary of State's Office, and the counties of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as a permanent injunction requiring the defendants to provide prepaid returnable envelopes for absentee ballots and absentee ballot applications.[SENTMARKER]The defendants opposed the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction on July 10, 2014.

gold_sents: This suit was brought on May 19, 2020, by two non-profit organizations and three voter plaintiffs against the state of Louisiana to challenge Louisiana’s Excuse Requirement, Witness Requirement, and Cure Prohibition.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the defendants from enforcing the Excuse and Witness Requirement, as well as provide absentee voters with notice and opportunity to cure defects in their absentee ballots for all elections in 2020 held in Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, the court dismissed the case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 4, 2020, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief respecting Louisiana’s voting regulations in light of COVID-19 (the "Virus").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's failure to provide absentee voters notice and an opportunity to cure defects in their absentee ballot request forms and their absentee ballots so they may be counted will disenfranchise Louisiana voters.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that Louisiana's Excuse Requirement, Witness Requirement, and Cure Prohibition violated their constitutional rights.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2020, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified voters to vote absentee ballot for the June 9, 2020 primary and the June 23, 2020 runoff election due to the current state of emergency.[SENTMARKER]On September 15, 2020, the court in a separate case enjoined the witness requirement for all South Carolina voters in the upcoming November 2020 General Election.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.

gold_sents: On June 21, 2016, individuals who had been forced to pay a $50 "extension fee" for inability to pay their monetary penalties in full, or go to gail for non-payment of court fines and costs, brought a putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Bogalusa City Court and the sole judge who sits on the Bogalusa City Court, under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the defendants (1) systematically jail and threaten to jail individuals who cannot pay fines and court costs that fund the city court; and (2) have created an illegal extension fee to generate additional revenue.[SENTMARKER]Shortly after U.S. District Court Judge Ivan L.R.[SENTMARKER]Lemelle denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and held their request for a preliminary injunction in abeyance, the parties decided to explore settlement options.[SENTMARKER]They filed a stipulated agreement with the District Court, which was granted.

gold_sents: On October 31st, 2016, a group of Plaintiffs who had been jailed for their inability to pay fines owed to the City of Florissant, Missouri for traffic tickets or other minor municipal offenses, sued the City for this violation of due process.[SENTMARKER]This case is still in the discovery stage and has been ongoing for four years.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
